title: Free mask, puppet-making workshop at Farnsworth
text:
Free mask, puppet-making workshop at Farnsworth Oct 02, 2015 The artistic director of Portland’s Shoestring Theater will lead a free weeklong workshop for all ages in Rockland at the Farnsworth Art Museum’s Gamble Center. 
Rockland — In conjunction with the museum’s annual Fall Family Festival, the Farnsworth Art Museum will host a weeklong mask and puppet-making workshop, taught by Nance Parker, artistic director of the Shoestring Theater in Portland. 
The free workshop will run Monday through Saturday, Oct. 12 through 17. Monday’s session will be held from noon to 4 p.m.; the Tuesday through Friday sessions will run from 2 to 6 p.m.; and Saturday’s from noon to 3 p.m. in the museum’s Gamble Education Center, on the corner of Grace and Union streets. 
All ages are invited to learn the process of creating, designing and building a personal mask. Participants will be expected to use their wildest ideas about creatures and myths when designing their work. Puppets will be executed sculpting clay, paper-mache and wire, in addition to adding hand-sewn costumes to create creatures both magical and scary. 
There also will also be an ongoing, group project of building a large parading puppet. These will be part of the Fall Family Festival Parade, which will depart from the Farnsworth’s Gamble Education Center Saturday, Oct. 17, at 5:30 p.m. 
While the mask & puppet-making studio times are flexible, participants should be willing to commit to multiple visits in order to complete a personal mask and allowing drying time in between sessions. Participants should be old enough to work independently, or have adult supervision. The workshop also is open to adults without accompanying children. 
Although drop-ins are welcome, advance reservations are greatly appreciated; email the Farnsworth’s Education Department at kfinlay@farnsworthmuseum.org.
